Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Award Grant: Advancing the Complex Product Design Using Virtual Reality Techniques

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Prairie View A&M University's Research Initiation Award entitled - Advancing the Complex Product Design Using Virtual Reality Techniques - has the goal to advance the ability of complex product design especially freeform shape modeling with Virtual Reality techniques. The objective is to investigate a virtual sculpting modeling and simulation technique for freeform geometry design with heterogeneous material. By introducing material heterogeneities, the freeform can obtain anisotropic properties, achieve advantages of various materials, and avoid the problem of material incompatibility. The approach is to apply a virtual sculpting method by interactively carving a workpiece using a virtual tool. Boolean operations between the model and the tool are executed to change the geometry and materials of the design model simultaneously. Haptic interface is incorporated to reflect the interaction between the tool and the model during the sculpting process. The virtual sculpting process is then integrated into the large scale PowerWall virtual environment.

The project presents a new method of creating a freeform model with heterogeneous materials in an intuitive and interactive manner using virtual sculpting. By integrating the process with haptic interface and PowerWall virtual environment, the product design quality will be improved and the product design cycle will be shortened. The research has potential applications in composite materials, nano-technology, bio-engineering, and medical simulations.

The education goal is to enhance the quality of engineering students and increase the number of African-American students pursuing engineering careers at Prairie View A&M University. This will be accomplished through curriculum development, student mentoring, and outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Research Initiate Award project has both the research and educational goals. The research goal was to advance the ability of complex product design and virtual prototyping using Virtual Reality techniques. The educational goals were: 1) to improve the students’ learning by applying virtual reality simulations in the teaching; 2) to involve and mentor underrepresented students in research projects; 3) to inspire K-12 students by introducing them the new virtual reality technologies.

The project investigated a new method of creating freeform model with heterogeneous material in an intuitive and interactive manner using virtual sculpting. Virtual sculpting is a process in which the user creates a 3D model on a computer screen by interactively carving a workpiece like a real sculptor would do on a piece of clay, wax or wood. The virtual sculpting system is augmented by haptic interface in a large-scale PowerWall virtual environment (VE). The research issues include solid modeling, stereographic rendering, and haptic interface. With the implementation of stereoscopic visual feedback and haptic force feedback in an immersive PowerWall virtual environment, the designer would appreciate a much better understanding of the 3D shape geometry and can explore through the 3D scene like he can do in the real world. As a consequence, the product design quality will be improved, product design cycle will be shortened, and the cost of design and manufacturing will be reduced.

The RIA project has provided students the opportunities for training and professional development. Two graduate students and five undergraduate students were mentored by the PI to take on the research tasks in this project. Three students are members of underrepresented minority group. Three students are female students. Students were also supported to participate in seminars and research symposiums, such as Texas A&M University System Pathways Student Research Symposium. This project has allowed students to learn about academic research. The project has provided them with improved skills related to programming, technical writing, professional presentation, and communication.

The results of this project have been disseminated to communities of interest. The project has produced 2 journal papers, 2 theses, 3 conference papers, and 4 posters. The Virtual Reality simulations have been demonstrated to high school students and guests through various outreach events. 203 undergraduate students in 5 different classes participated in the virtual reality simulations as part of their classes. More than 90% of the participants are African-American students.

The RIA grant has enhanced the research and teaching infrastructure at Prairie View A&M University. The project has benefited the students from several departments including Mechanical Engineering, Electrical Engineering, and Chemical Engineering. The RIA grant has significant impact on broadening the participation of minority students.
